3:
There he broke the flaming arrows that his enemies shot,
\q2 and he also broke their shields and swords and other weapons that they used in battles.
\b
\q1
4:
God, you are powerful! You are like a great king
\q as you return from the mountains where you defeated your enemies.
\q1
5:
Their brave soldiers were killed, and then those who killed them took away everything that those soldiers had.
\q1 Those enemies died;
\q2 indeed, none of them were able to fight any longer.
\q1
6:
When you, the God whom Jacob worshiped, rebuked your enemies,
\q2 their horses and their riders fell down dead.
\q1
7:
Truly, you cause everyone to be afraid.
\q1 When you are angry and you punish people, no one can endure it.
\q1
8:
From heaven you proclaimed that you would judge people,
\q2 and then everyone on the earth was afraid and did not say anything more
\q2
9:
when you arose to declare that you would punish wicked people
\q2 and rescue all those whom they had oppressed.
\b
\q1
10:
When you punish those with whom you are angry, your people will praise you,
\q2 and your enemies who survive will worship you on your festival days.
\b
\q1
12:
He humbles the leaders,
\q2 and terrifies all the kings.
76:
\d A psalm written by Asaph for the choir director, to be accompanied by stringed instruments
\b
\q1
